box.hint: Create menu of current MIDI controllers

box.text: Often, and especially when dealing with weird phenomenoms like FM synthesis, it is easier to start working from an empirical situation, rather than trying to define immediately what one precisely needs. Only a very few really understand how FM synthesis works (not the author...). This patch might help you to get even more lost in the sound ether. Sometimes it's nice, sometime it's not...
This options permits the decision, once the envelopes are being generated, to give them (or not) all the same duration.

Save (and name) your settings. Shift-click on a slot to store a preset, click to recall, option-shift click to delete (with "help in locked patchers" option deactivated). Presets are saved together with the patch.

Simply select the parameter to be modified. There are two axes of selection : the type of parameter, and the type of section of parameters. So, for instance, one might want to modify all the LFO frequencies, but not in the Mod section. Similarly, one might like to modify the envelope of each section, but not their other parameters.
This coefficient is widely used all over the patch, in order to offer a simple but efficient control on variations of values.

Time values for time parameters are also generated according to the desired type of unit. So, for instance, if one only wants to generate values such as 4ths, 8ths or 16ths, one should select the "note" item.

Parameters such as LFO frequencies, envelope segment, ADSR, etc. are generated relatively to a master tempo clock. To summarize, the faster the tempo is set, the "faster" those parameters will (have a chance to) be. Synchronizing time values can produce a more "dynamic" overall sound.
Time units (durations, lfo speeds, etc.) will be chosen according to the type selected.
